Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: With the increasing importance of portable and wearable electronic technologies, new materials are needed that combine superlative electronic properties with other requirements such as mechanical flexibility, low power consumption, and scalable manufacturing. Emerging two-dimensional nanoelectronic materials that are atomically thin meet many of these requirements, but no single material can achieve all of them concurrently. Consequently, this project develops heterostructures that synergistically integrate the desirable properties of multiple two-dimensional nanoelectronic materials, thus overcoming the design tradeoffs imposed by single materials utilized in isolation. Solution-processing methods are further employed to achieve highly homogenous nanoelectronic heterostructures in a manner that is compatible with large-scale, low-cost additive manufacturing. The results of this project are disseminated through a comprehensive set of education and outreach activities that include graduate curriculum development, undergraduate laboratories, and a materials science exhibit at the Chicago Museum of Science and Industry.

Technical Description: To realize reproducibly high performance in electronic and optoelectronic devices, nanoelectronic materials must be produced via scalable methods that possess high structural monodispersity. Furthermore, the resulting nanoelectronic material components need to be assembled into morphologies that preserve their superior properties and are amenable to subsequent fabrication methods. Towards these goals, dispersion chemistries, solvents, and density gradient media are identified that enable density gradient ultracentrifugation sorting of transition metal dichalcogenides, boron nitride, and black phosphorus with exceptional structural and electronic purities. These high purity samples facilitate fundamental studies of two-dimensional nanoelectronic materials as a function of structural parameters such as thickness and lateral size. In addition, homogeneous two-dimensional nanomaterial dispersions are assembled via vacuum filtration and layer-by-layer assembly to form multi-component bulk heterojunction nanocomposite films and thin-film heterostructures that are suitable for the fabrication and testing of large-area nanoelectronic devices and circuits. In this manner, the role of surface and interfacial chemistry on electronic properties are elucidated at the two-dimensional limit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

In order to realize reproducibly high performance in electronic and optoelectronic devices, nanoelectronic materials must be produced via scalable methods that possess high structural monodispersity. Furthermore, the resulting nanoelectronic material populations need to be assembled into morphologies that preserve their superlative properties and are amenable to subsequent fabrication methods. Towards these ends, this grant has developed a series of density gradient ultracentrifugation (DGU) methods that enable the scalable separation of 2D materials (e.g., hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) and transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs)) by thickness and lateral size. The resulting monodisperse 2D materials were assembled into thin films using layer-by-layer assembly, vacuum filtration, spin coating, and drop casting, thereby enabling the fabrication and testing of electronic and optoelectronic devices. Specific intellectual merit accomplishments include:

(1)   Isopycnic DGU enabled the preparation of thickness-sorted hBN, which was subsequently layer-by-layer assembled into ultrathin dielectrics with low leakage currents and high capacitances.  The resulting solution-processed hBN dielectric films were used to fabricate graphene transistors with negligible hysteresis and high mobilities.

(2)   Exfoliation and stable dispersion of MoS2 in aqueous solution was achieved using amphiphilic block copolymers. The resulting exfoliation and dispersion conditions were found to be generally applicable to a range of related 2D materials (e.g., MoSe2, WSe2, WS2, SnSe, and hBN), allowing the formation of diverse 2D material heterostructures.

(3)   Black phosphorus (BP) was exfoliated in deoxygenated aqueous surfactant solutions. The use of deoxygenated water prevented sample degradation as confirmed by spectroscopic analysis. Due to the high exfoliation efficiency of this process, the resulting phosphorene flakes are thinner than anhydrous organic solvent dispersions, thus allowing the observation of layer-dependent photoluminescence down to the monolayer limit.

(4)   Indium selenide (InSe) dispersions were produced using a surfactant-free, low boiling point, deoxygenated ethanol/water co-solvent system. When employed in photodetectors, individual InSe nanosheets exhibited photoresponsivities that exceeded the highest value of any solution-processed monolithic semiconductor to date.

(5)   Solution processing strategies were developed for additional chemically reactive 2D monochalcogenides. For example, anhydrous organic solvent exfoliation enabled solution processing of electrochemically active GeS, which was shown to yield unprecedentedly high cycling stability and rate performance as an anode material in lithium-ion batteries.   In addition, surfactant-free, deoxygenated co-solvent processing was extended to GaTe, resulting in optoelectronically active thin films that are stable at high light intensities and thus suitable for high-performance, large-area photodetectors.

(6)   A variety of methods were competitively evaluated for the formation of electronically percolating thin films based on monodisperse solution-processed 2D materials including vacuum filtration, drop casting, spin coating, dip coating, spray coating, blade coating, and layer-by-layer assembly. Collaborative work with IBM further showed the compatibility of solution-processed 2D materials with wafer-scale dielectrophoretic assembly on pre-patterned graphene electrode arrays.

 

Broader Impacts:

In addition to high impact publications, this grant resulted in substantial intellectual property and commercialization opportunities.  The latest developments in solution-processed monodisperse nanoelectronic heterostructures were also be incorporated into education and outreach activities that target graduate and undergraduate students, K-12 students, and the general public.  Specific broader impacts include: 

(1)  PhD student training: This grant provided partial to full support of 4 PhD students in Materials Science and Engineering including one U.S. Navy Veteran via a Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences Graduate Research Supplement for Veterans.

(2)  Undergraduate and MS student training: 5 undergraduate researchers and 3 MS students, including 2 under-represented minority and 4 female students, were affiliated with this grant via Research Experience for Undergraduates and related academic programs.

(3)  Industrial partners and commercialization activities: External partners on this grant include several companies (e.g., NanoIntegris, Raymor Industries, MilliporeSigma, and IBM T. J. Watson Research Center). NanoIntegris was co-founded by PI Mark Hersam and has licensed multiple DGU patents. In addition, multiple nanomaterial inks from the Hersam Laboratory are available commercially from MilliporeSigma.

(4)  International partners: Active international collaborations include IBM Research Brazil on solution-processed black phosphorus electronic and optoelectronic devices and the University of Chemistry and Technology (Prague, Czech Republic) on monochalcogenide 2D materials. The latter collaboration was established while PI Mark Hersam was serving as U.S. Science Envoy to Eastern Europe on behalf of the U.S. State Department in 2016.

(5)  Curriculum development: PI Mark Hersam serves as the Director of the Hierarchical Materials Graduate Program, which provides opportunities for interdisciplinary materials research in addition to coursework with three themes: (1) Synthesis and Processing; (2) Multi-Scale Imaging and Characterization; (3) Multi-Scale Modeling and Analysis.

(6)  Pre-college education and outreach: PI Mark Hersam serves as the Chief Advisor for Tau Beta Pi (undergraduate engineering honor society). Tau Beta Pi has an extensive K-12 education and outreach program including M.E.S.S. (Matsci Exposing Students to Science) that makes visits to elementary and high schools, particularly in the socioeconomically diverse Chicago Public Schools, for interactive science lectures and demonstrations.
